bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kêtahtawê wawêyiw wîsahkêcâhk ; sipwêhtêw . Once upon a time Wisahketchahk got ready and went forth.
êkwah mostoswah wâpamêw . Then he saw a buffalo.
wîh-tapasiyiwah . It started to run away.
cêskwa , nisîm ! itêw . “Wait a bit, Little Brother!” he said to it.
êkwah nakîwak ôki mostoswak . Then the buffalo stopped.
mah , kitapwêsin , itêw . “Why, you are all hot!” he said to it.
êkwah watayihk is-sâminêw . Then he felt its belly.
êkotê ohci tahkamêw môhkomân . He stabbed it from there with his knife.
êkwah mâh-maniswêw . Then he cut pieces from it.
pa-pimisin , êkwah wiyâsah êh-pimastât , ê-wîh-mîcisot . He lay there, having placed the pieces of meat along the ground, intending to eat.
êkwah ayih oskanah cîkaham , pimiy êh-osîhtât ; And the bones he broke, to make fat;
wîhkwâhk asiwatâw . he put it into the bladder.
êkwah itohtêw sîpîhk . Then he went to the river.
wâpamêw ayi wacaskwah . He saw some muskrats. CHECK ayi
âstam , nisîmitik , itêw ; “Come here, Little Brothers,” he said to them;

seg.gloss: “I want this stuff to get cool.”

p.seg: miyêw oma pimiy . He gave them the fat.
osôyiyihk tahkopitam . He tied it to the tail of one.
sipwêhtêw sîpîhk wacask , pimiy anima ê-tahkatiniyik , êh-papâmiskât . Then the muskrat went off into the river, so that the fat cooled off as it swam about.
kâya sêkimin , nistêsêh , itwêw wacask . “Don't call out and frighten me,” said the muskrat.
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk askamawêw sakâhk . Then Wisahketchahk watched it from the brush.
sîpîhk sisonêh ê-kwêskosimât , sêkimêw wacaskwah . From the bank of the stream he whistled at the muskrat and frightened it.
tapasîw wacask ; koskopayihtâw ôma pimiy ; êkwah sîpîhk pimâhotêw . The muskrat fled; it spilled the fat; the fat floated on the water.
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk pimipahtâw sîpiy ôm âyi ê-sâ-sôpahtahk pimiy , sîpîhk . Then Wisahketchahk ran and lapped up the fat from the river. CHECK ayi
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk kisiwâsiw . Angry was Wisahketchahk.

seg.q:
ayîsiyiniwak
pîstêw
t-êtwêwak êkw ôma pimiy .

seg.gloss: It was I who created this earth;

seg.q: kîhkîhk ka-nakiskâtin , wacask ; kihkîhk ka-nakiskâtn , niy âskiy kâ-kî-osîhtâyân !
seg.gloss: in spite of all, I shall meet you, Muskrat, I who created this earth!”

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêw wîsahkêcâhk . Then Wisahketchahk went away.
êkosi misi-sakâw wâpahtam . Then he saw a big forest.
êkwah piponiyiw ; kawaciw mitonih . Now it was winter; he was very cold.
swâsisah mâh-mêtawêyiwah . children were playing there.

âstam , nisîm , itêw ,
tân ânim âyi okimâw wîkih ? “Come here, Little Brother,” he said to one; “Which is the chief's tent?”
kiskinôhamâk ; itohtêw . The boy pointed it out to him, and he went there.
êkwah pîhtokêw . He entered.

êkwah nâpêw awah ,
tawâw , nistêsê ! The man there called, “Come in, my elder brother!”
apiw wêskwâhtêmihk . He sat down opposite the door.
asamâw okiniyah , pimihkân . He was given wild quinces to eat, in the form of pemican.

seg.gloss: early in the morning we move camp.”

p.seg: âhci pikô kêtayôwinisêw wîsahkêcâhk . In spite of the warning, Wisahketchahk undressed.
akotâw êh-pâsahk otayôwinisah . He hung up his clothes to dry.
êkwah kawisimôw . Then he lay down.
êkwah mitonih kisinâw . It was very cold.
kîkisêpâ mitoni ôhpahôwak pihêwak . Early in the morning a great many partridges flew up.
wîsahkêcâhk kônihk waskic nipâw . Wisahketchahk was sleeping on the snow.
êkwah kisinâyiw mitonih . And it was very cold.
mistikohk akotêw ôw ayôwinisah . On a tree hung those clothes of his.
êkwah wîh-nipahaciw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was almost frozen to death.
pihêwak ôki piciwak . those partridges had moved camp.
kisiwâsiw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was angry.

seg.gloss: “I shall look for the partridges, I who created the world!”

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêw wîsahkêcâhk . Then Wisahketchahk went away from there.
kêtahtawê êh-pimohtêt , êh-nîpihk , kêkway ? - hen, at one time, as he was walking along, in summer, what was that? --
pihêsisah wâpamêw wacistwanihk . some young partridges he saw in a nest.

seg.gloss: “Why, you have just called us by name!”
Ever do people have two names.

p.seg:
êkwah ôki pihêsisak :
okoskohiwêsîsak nitisiyihkâsônân . Then those partridge-chicks: “Little Winged Startlers we are called.”
wacistwanih mîsîw . he muted upon the nest.
êkosi sipwêhtêw . Then he departed.
sipwêhtêw êkosi wîsahkêcâhk . Then Wisahketchahk departed.
êkwah pihêwak ôki takosinwak wacistwanihk . Then the old partridges came to their nest.
kisiwâsiwak , ocawâsimisiwâwah êh-mîcitimiht . They were angry that their young had been befouled.
êkwah sipwêhtêwak pihêwak . They went away.
mâwacihitôwak . They made an assembly.
êkwah sipwêhtêwak mihcêt . Many of them set out.
âyîtawâkâm sîpîsisihk apiwak . on both banks of the little stream they sat.
êkwah êkotah wîsahkêcâhk pê-pimohtêw . Then Wisahketchahk came walking along.
aciyaw wâpahtam omah sîpîsis . Soon he saw the brook.

seg.gloss: Four times I shall run at this brook.

p.seg: êkwah wayacâwiw , sîpîsisihk ê-ispahtât . he took a running start, heading for the brook.
tâpiskôc ê-wîh-pâsic-ôhpît , pôyôw . At the very point of jumping across, he halted.
âsa min âsahtêw . Again he walked back.
âsa mina wayacâwiw . Again he took a running start.
êkwah nika-pâsic-ôhpîn , itwêw . “Now I shall jump across,” he said.
êkwah môskîstam êkwah . So now he made for it.
mwêhc êh-ôhpît , misahc ôhpîwak pihêwak . ust as he jumped, up went the partridges.
tâwakâm pahkisin . He fell square into the water.
ocahpîhcisah wanihêw nipîhk . He lost his tobacco-pouch in the water.
kêtahtawêh akwâyâhokôw . In time the water carried him to the bank.
pa-pimisin sisonêh nipîhk . He lay there by the water's edge.
êkwah waniskâw ; ocâhpîhcisah ntonawêw . hen he got up; he looked for his tobacco-pouch.
nama kêkway miskawêw . He could not find it at all.
kêtahtawêh êh-itâpit , nipîhk akohciniyiwa . Then once, as he looked that way, it lay there in the water.
ntonawêw . He looked for it.
êkwah pahkopêw . He went into the water.
namoya kîh-otinêw . He could not get hold of it.
asiskiy mânah kâskipitam , êh-ntôkâwinikêt . He merely clawed up mud whenever he made a grasp. possible êh-nitonikêt.
kapê-kîsik ayâw êkotah sîpîsîsihk . All day he was there in the brook.
kêtahtawê kapâw . At last he went back to the bank.
nêstosiw . He was tired.
kisiwâsiw , ohcâhpîhcisah êh-wanihât . He was angry at having lost his tobacco-pouch.
kêtahtawê itâpiw ; ispimihk wâpamêw êh-akociniyit . Then at one time he looked that way; he saw it hanging up aloft.
otinêw . He took it.

cê , macastimwak ! itêw ,
tâpwê nikisiwâhikwak . “Bah, the dirty dogs!” he said of them; “They surely have angered me!”
sipwêhtêw êkotah ohci . He went away from there.
sa-sipwêhtêw . He went from place to place.
êkwah wâpamêw misahkamik sîsîpah . Then he saw a great many ducks.
wîh-tapasîwak sîsîpak . The ducks started to flee.
cêskwa : nisîmitik , itêw . “Wait a bit, Little Brothers!” he called to them.
nayahcikêw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk carried something on his back.
wayêsihêw . He deceived them.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.
kêtahtawê sâkahikan ; mitoni misikamâw . There was a lake; it was a very big lake.
êkotah pimohtêw . He went thither.

nistêsê , itwêw sîsîp ,
kêkway kâ-nayahtaman ? “Big Brother,” said a duck, “what are you carrying on your back?”
êkwah mânokêw . Then he built a lodge.
êkwah mâwacihêw nanâtohk sîsîpah niskah . He assembled all kinds of ducks and geese.
sôskwât êkwah pîhtokêw , êkwah sîsîpak misahkamik , ê-wîh-nîmihitocik . Then at once he entered, and all the ducks were to dance.

seg.gloss: “You will close your eyes for this dance of yours.”

p.seg: êhag , itwêwak sîsîpak . “Yes”, said the ducks.
êkwah mâci-nikamôw . Then he began to sing.
nîmihitôwak êkwah sîsîpak ; mâka pasikwâpiwak . Then the ducks danced; but they had their eyes closed.
ati-nipahêw ô sîsîpah , êh-ati-tahkamât oscikwânisiyihk . he set about killing those ducks by stabbing their little heads.
kêkâc êh-mêscihât , pêyak awah apisîsisiw napatê piko pasakwâpiw . When he had nearly finished all of them, one little fellow held only one eye shut.
wâpamêw . He saw him.
tapasîw ; êkwah pêyak sihkihp . He ran away; so did one other, the diver-duck.
nîso pikoh is-tapasîwak ; pimâtisiwak nîso pikoh . Only two of them thus escaped; only two got away with their lives.
êkwah mistahê pâhpiw . Then he laughed much.

seg.gloss: “I did not bring any dance at all.
Now I shall have plenty to eat.”

p.seg: pônam êkwah . Then he built a fire.
nawacîw . He set his food to cook.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.
nakatêw onawacîwinah . He left his roasts.
kêtahtawê êh-pimohtêt , wâpamêw mahkêsîsah . As he was walking, he saw a fox.
êh , cêskwa , nisîm , itêw ; “Hey, stop a bit, Little Brother!” he said to him;
awiyak nakasiwêcih , sîsîpah kahkiyaw ta-môwêw , itêw . Whichever wins will eat all the ducks,” he said to him.

êkwah mahkêsîs :
namoya ! niwîsakêyihtên niskât ; namoya , wîsahkêcâhk . Then the fox: “No. I have a sore leg; no, Wisahketchahk.”

seg.gloss: “I shall tie some stones to my leg.
That way you will outrun me.”

p.seg: êhag , itwêw mahkêsîs . “Very well,” said the fox.
êkwah tahkopitêw asiniyah oskâtihk wîsahkêcâhk . Then Wisahketchahk tied some stones to his leg.
êkwah sipwêhtêwak mitoni . Then they started off at a great rate.
namoya kîh-kisiskâhtêw wîsahkêcâhk ; osâm kosikwatiwak asiniyak . Wisahketchahk could not go fast; the stones were too heavy.
êkwah mahkêsîs watiskâw . And the fox limped.
têtipêwêwak ispatinâw . They ran round a hill.
âkawâyihk êh-ihtât mahkêsîs , mitoni sôhki pimipayiw . When the fox got out of sight behind it, he ran very well.
sîsîpah kahkiyaw ntawi-kitamwêw . He went and ate up all the ducks.
ositah pikô iskwastam . He ate all except the feet.
êkwah tapasîw . Then he ran away.
êh-otâkosihk takosin wîsahkêcâhk . At nightfall Wisahketchahk arrived.
ocipitêw sîsîpah pêyak . He pulled forth one duck.
nôsâmi-kîsiswâw , itwêw . “I have cooked him too long,” he said.
kotakah mîn ocipitêw ; piyis kahkiyaw . He pulled out another; finally all of them.
nôsâmihkânêcêposin , itwêw . “I am overdoing my roasts a bit,” he said.
êkwah kiskêyihtam . Then he understood.
mahkêsîsah kisiwâhik . He was angry at the fox.
sipwêhtêw ; ntonawêw mahkêsîsah . He went from there; he looked for the fox.
kêtahtawê êh-pa-pimohtêt miskawêw , êh-nipâyit timaskâhk . hen at one time, as he walked about, he found him sleeping in the tall grass.

seg.gloss: If I club him, I shall spoil the hide.
I shall have it for a tobacco-pouch.
I had better stifle him by building a fire round him.”

p.seg: wâsakâm saskaham maskosiyah . All around he set fire to the grass.
êkwah ti-kwâhkotêw . The flames spread.
êkwah mâhkêsîs kisiwâk êh-pê-kwâhkotêyik pasikosipahtâw . When the blaze came close, the fox jumped to his feet.
êkwah miywêyihtam , êh-pasikosipahtâyit . He was glad when the other jumped to his feet.
namoya nânitaw kikîh-itâmon , kâ-kitamwacik nisîsîpimak , yahâh , yahâh ! itêw . “You cannot escape anywhere, you who ate all my ducks, yahaw, yahaw!” he said to him.
êkwah ôhi makhkêsîsah pêhêw . Then he waited for the fox.

êkwah pâhpiw ,
mistahi nipahîhkaswâw , êy-itêyihtahk . He laughed, thinking, “I am certainly killing him with this fire!”

êkwah êh-âstawiyik , nama kêkway mahkêsîs . But when the fire subsided, there was no fox. LB: Not “bad grammar” or simplification for my benefit: the Sweet Grass people regularly use {nama kîkway} with animates, as, {nama kîkway ayôskanak}: “There aren't any (more) raspberries.”
tapasîw . He had run away.
ôhcitaw ka-miskâtn , itêw . All the more surely will I find you!” he said of him.
pimitisahwêw . He pursued him.
kêtahtawê ê-pa-pimohtêt , pêhtam êh-matwê-pâh-pâhpiyihk . Then once, as he walked along, he heard loud and repeated laughter. CHECK -yihk. Obviative impersonal?? HCW: ??
kwêsk îtohtêw sakâhk : nama kêkway . He went into the brush at either side: nothing.

âsa mna sipwêhtêw ; kêtahtawê kâ-wâpamât picikîskisîsah êh-yâ-yakonamiyit oskîsikosiyiwah , êh-âh-akociwêpinamiyit sakâhk , êkwah êh-koskwâskopitamiyit , kâwi mânah êh-tâpiskopayiyikih . He went on again; soon he saw some jays pulling out their eyes and tossing them so they caught in the brush, and shaking the bushes, whereupon the eyes would spring back into place. LB on {picikîskisîsah}: Bird not identified.

seg.gloss: “What is the idea of this, Little Brother?”
“Because I have a headache we are doing this.”
I have an everlasting pain in my head.”
“Do take pity on me, Little Brothers.
Right now I feel the old pain coming back in my head.”
I will give you four doses.

seg.q: têstikwânêyini , kâya wiya nôhtaw , mêyâkwâm , nistêsê .
seg.gloss: When you have a headache, not at any other time; don't forget, Big Brother!”

p.seg: miyik nêwâw ta-yâ-yakonahk oskîsikwah . They gave him the power to pull out his eyes four times.

seg.gloss: I shall be having a cruel headache.”

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went from there.
namoya wâhyaw ihtâw ; mamâhpinêw . He had not gone far; he began to groan.

seg.gloss: “There is my head tormenting me as usual!”

p.seg: sakâhk itohtêw . He went into the brush.
yâ-yakonam oskîsikwah . He pulled out both his eyes.
akociwêpinam . He threw them onto a bush.
êkwah mistikw êh-ocipitât , kâwi ô-pahkihtiniyiwa oskîsikwa . Then, when he pulled at the bush, his eyes fell from it, back into place.
âsay mina sipwêhtêw . He set out again.
namoya wâhyaw itohtêw . He did not walk far.
âsa mînah wîsakêyihtam . Again he was in pain.
âsa mna sakâhk itohtêw . Again he stepped into the brush.
êkwah êkotah yâ-yakonam oskîsikwah . There he pulled out his eyes.
akociwêpinam . He threw them so that they caught and hung.
êkwah ât êh-ocipitahk , nama kêkway . But then, though he tugged at the bush, they were not there.
mahkêsîs awa kwâsihtâw oskîsikoyiwa wîsahkêcâhkwah . That fox had stolen Wisahketchahk's eyes.
êkwah namoya wâpiw . So now he was blind.
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk âh-ocipitêw kapê-kîsik . Then Wisahketchahk kept tugging at the tree all day.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.
namoya wâpiw . He was blind.
êkw âwa mahkêsîs mistik otinam ; nakiskawêw ; cahkâpahwêw . And the fox took a stick; he went to meet him; he jabbed him in the sockets of his eyes.

hmm , itwêw ,
nicâhkâpicinin , êkw êh-pimohtêt . Hum,” he said, “I am getting snagged in my eye-holes,” and walked on.
pônihêw êkwah mahkêsîs awah . Then the fox left him alone.
kêtahtawê tawikisin . Then at one time he bumped into something.
kêkway kiya mistik ? itêw . “What sort of tree are you?” he asked it.

seg.gloss: “That is not the kind I want.”

p.seg: âsa mna sipwêhtêw . He set out again.
âsa mna tawikisin . Again he bumped.
êkwah ntonawêw pikiwah ; miskawêw . Then he sought rosin; he found it.
êkwah osîhtâw oskîsikwah êwakonih ohci pikiwah . Then he made eyes for himself out of that rosin.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.

seg.q: âhah kiya kâ-kisiwâhiyan , mahkêsîs , kâ-câh-câhkâpahôwin , kiwîh-ntonâtin .
seg.gloss: “Now, as for you, Fox, who angered me by jabbing me in the eyes, I shall look for you.
When I find you, I shall kill you.”

p.seg: sipwêhtêw êkwah . Then he went from there.
êkwah pa-pimohtêw . He walked along.
kêtahtawêh kâ-pêhtahk êh-nipâkwêsimôwiht . Then at one time he heard a Sun-Dance going on.
êkwah pimipahtâw . He ran.
nêtohtahkih , wâhyaw kâ-matwê-npakwêsimôwiht . Whenever he listened, far off was the noise of the Sun-Dance.
êkosi êkwah wâpahtam ostikwân êh-astêyik ôcêwah êh-tasîhkamiyit . At last he saw the head of an animal lying on the ground, with flies busy all over it.
âkâwâtamawêw . He envied them for it.

nisîmitik , nîsta nik-ôcân , itêw . “Little Brothers, I too shall be a fly,” he said to them. LB on {nik-ôcân}: The demoninative of {ocêw}: “fly”, is {ocêwiw}, used below; here the humorous formation is as though there were a primitive verb stem {ocâ-}: “to be a fly.”

seg.gloss: “Little Brothers, please let me be a fly.”
“Little Brothers, please grant me what I beg.”
“Well then, let our older brother be a little one, a fly.”

p.seg: â , namoya , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ; “Oh dear, no,” said Wisahketchahk;

seg.gloss: “I shall be very large; I shall be a big fly.”

p.seg: â , kiyâm , nistêsê , k-âpsîsisin , itik . “Oh, now, Big Brother, do please be small!” they asked him.
êkwah ôcêwiw . So he became a fly.
kîtahtawê kwêskimôw ; kâw âyîsiyiniwiw ; pasikôw ; misiwêw ostikwân oma sipwêhtatâw . Suddenly he changed his form; he turned back into human shape; he arose; he carried off the whole head.
kikamoyiw wâwâskêsiwistikwân ostikwânihk . The deer's-head was fastened over his head.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . So he went away.
namoya kî-kisiskâhtêw . He could not go fast.
nama kêkway is-wâpiw . He could not see at all, the way he was fixed.
kêtahtawê sisonê sîpîhk pimohtêw . After a while he was walking along the bank of a stream.
tihtipipayiw . He fell and rolled.
pimâhokôw sîpîhk . The water carried him along in the river.
kêtahtawê ôki ayîsiyiniwak wâpamêwak , êh-pimâhôkôyit . Soon the people saw him drifting along.
êkwah nôtokêsiw cîkahikan otinam , ê-wîh-nipahât . An old woman took an axe to kill him.
pahkopêw , ê-wîh-pakamahwât wâwâskêsiwah . She went into the water to club the deer.
pasikosipahtâw wîsahkêcâhk ; tapasîw . Wisahketchahk jumped to his feet; he ran away.
pahkisin mistasiniyah êh-apiyit ; pâskihtitâw . He fell where a big boulder lay; he smashed the head as he fell.
êkwah nôtokêsiw pimitisahwêw . The old woman was chasing him.
êyakô mâka mînah wîsahkêcâhk ! itwêw ; pâhpiw . “Why, it's Wisahketchahk again!” she said; she laughed.
wîsahkêcâhk tapasîw . Wisahketchahk ran away.
pônâmôw ; êkotah ohc êkwah sipwêhtêw . He stopped in his flight; then he again made off from that place.
pimohtêw , kâ-wâpamât niskah . As he walked along, he saw some geese.
wîh-tapasîwak niskak . The geese tried to get away.
êkosi nakiwak . So they stopped.
êkwah otihtêw . He stepped up to them.
nisîmitik , nîstah nika-niskiwin , itêw . “Little Brothers, I too shall be a goose,” he said to them.
piyisk sâkôcimêw . At last he persuaded them.
niskiwiw . He became a goose.
êkwah , nistêsê , ayîsiyiniwak wâpamatwâwi , ôhpimêh ka-pimihân , itêw . “And now, Big Brother, whenever you see people, off to one side you will fly,” one said to him.
êkwah mîcisôwak êkotah sâkahikanihk . Then they ate, there in the lake.
kêtahtawê ohpahôwak . Presently they flew up.
nîkâniw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was in the lead.
ayîsiyiniwah ntonawêw ohcitaw . He looked for people, just to be contrary.
piyisk miskawêw , tahkih cîk êkotah êh-pimihât . At last he found them, and kept flying close to where they were.
êkwah mâkwêyimowak niskak ; tapasîwak . The geese became worried; they fled.
êkwah wiya wîsahkêcâhk êkotah ati-pimihâw . But Wisahketchahk flew on in that place.
pâh-pâskiswâw . He began to be shot at.

êh-wî-tapasît , pôskôpayihêw otaskêkinwah ; pitihkwaskamikisin . When he made to flee, he burst the skin he had been given; down he went with a crash. CHECK pitihkwaskamikisin. HCW: Probably lexicon error.
nôtokêsiw wâpamêw . An old woman saw him.
tâpiskôc niskah êh-itêyihtamahk wîsahkêcâhk ! itwêw ; “It was Wisahketchahk we thought was a goose!” she said;
âsa mînah pâhpiw . she laughed some more.
êkwah mînah êkotah ohci sipwêhtêw . Then he went away from that place, too.
nôhtêhkatêw ; nama kêkway mîciw . He was hungry; he had nothing to eat.
êkwah nicawâc wîh-kakwê-minahôw . He decided to try and kill some game.
wâpamêw mostoswah nêwo ; nama nânitaw isi kîh-nipahêw . He saw four buffalos; he had no way of killing them.
papâmohtêw . He walked about.
kêtahtawê oyahpitam mistikwah , ayîsiyiniwah êh-osîhât , tâpiskôc êh-mâsihitôwit ; Soon he tied up some sticks, arranging them like men wrestling;
êkwah mostoswah itohtêw . then he went to where the buffalo were.
wîh-tapasiyiwah . They started to run away.
cêskwah , nisîm , itêw , “Wait, Little Brothers!” he called to them;

seg.q:
nêk âyîsiyiniwak kâ-mâsihitôcik ,
takwâhnâwak wihcêkisiwak , êh-twêt pêyak anah , êkwah kotak anah ,
namoya , êh-twit ,
nawac iyâpêsisak , êh-itwêt ,
seg.gloss: Those men are wrestling over there, because one of them said, 'Bulls stink,' and the other said, 'No. young steers are worse,'
that is the reason they are fighting;
but I have come to smell you.”

p.seg: êkwah otinam kîmôc omôhkomân . Then secretly he took his knife.
êkwah sîpâh ê-siniskêyit , ê-wîh-miyâmât takwâhnâwa , tahkamêw ; npahêw . Then when he hold his arm out under the bull, to smell him, he stabbed him; he killed him.
nîso nipahêw . He killed two of them.
nnôhtêhkatâwâ ! itwêw . It's hungry I was!” said he.
pâhpiw mistahi . He laughed a great deal.

seg.gloss: “When I just made the thing, and there isn't any man there!”

p.seg: âsa mina pâhpiw . Again he laughed.
êkwah wiya pahkwêkiswêw . Then he skinned them.
osîhtâw êkwah wiyâsah . And he prepared the meat.
êkwah êh-kîh-kîsihtât , pa-pimisin . When he had got it ready, he lay there.

seg.gloss: I shall eat a huge amount.”

p.seg: êkwah mistikwah ah-cimasôwit tâwâyihk pimisin . He lay down between two trees. CHECK {ah-cimasoyit}
piyis mâkwâskwahôk mistikwah . At last he was tightly held by the trees.
micimôsôw mistikohk . he was caught between the trees.
pê-takopahtâw êkotah mahîhkanis . A young wolf came running up.
niwiyâsimah mâka mîna ka-wîhkohkân , itêw . “You'll be inviting people, as usual, to dine on my meat,” he said to him.
mâci-mîcisoyiwah . The other began to eat.
ostikwân pikô waskawinam . All he could do was turn his head.
kêtahtawê êkwah ôyôyôw êôkô mayîhkanis ; After a while the young wolf began to howl;
pikw îtêh ohci pâpahtâwak mahîhkanak mahkêsisak kîhkwahâkêsak , ahâsiwak mînah . from every direction they came running, wolves, foxes, coyotes, and crows.
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk owiyâsimah kahkiyaw maskahtôyiwah ; ayis wiya micimôsôw mistikohk ; They scrambled for Wisahketchahk's meat and took it all; for he was caught between the trees;
nama kêkway ôhtahtam owiyâsimah . and so he ate none of his meat.
miton êh-kitânawêyit , êkwah pihkohôw . Only after the others had made a clean sweep of it, did he get himself free.
êkwah kisiwâsiw . Then he was angry.
pah-pasastêhwêw mistikwah kâ-kîh-mâkwâskwahokot . he beat the trees that had held him fast.
kitamwêyiwa mahîhkanah . the wolves had eaten them up.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.
wâpamêw mostoswah . He saw some buffalo.
kisiwâk êh-otihtât , mitoni kâ-misi-pwêkitôt . when he got near, he noisily broke wind.
tapasiyiwah . They fled.
kisiwâsiw . He got angry.
âsa mîna nâciyôstawêw kotakah . He stole up to another.
mwêhci minah kisiwâk êh-otihtât , kâ-misi-pwêkitot ; osahamâk . Again, just as he got near it, he loudly broke wind; it drove away his prey.
sipwêhtêw . He went from there.

seg.gloss: “In this you anger me, that you drive them away from me.

p.seg: êkwah ntonawêw asiniyah . Then he looked for a stone.
miskawêw êh-misikitiyit mitonih . He found a very large one.
êkwah pônam . Then he made a big fire.
kisâpiskiswêw ; mitoni wâsêyâpiskiswêw . He heated the stone; he heated it to a bright glow.
êkwah miton ê-kîsi-wâsêyâpiskiswât , kêtayôwinisêw . When he had got it to white heat, he took off his clothes.
êkwah têhtapiw . Then he sat down on it.

côwêhkasôw ;
css ! côwêhkasôw . He sizzled as he burned: “Hiss!” he sizzled.

seg.gloss: “Why are you bound to cry out like that?
You drove off my game when I was going to bag it.”

p.seg: êkwah kâ-sipwêhtêt , namoya kîh-pimohtêw . Then, when he set out, he could not walk.
kinwês papâmohtêw . For a long time he wandered about.
kêtahtawê miskam mînisah ; mihcêniyiwa . Presently he found some berries; there were many of them.
êkwah pêyak nakiskawêw . Then he encountered one.
pêyahtik , nistêsê , itik , “Go easy, Brother,” it said to him;
mihcêtiwak wâkayôsak , itik . “There are many bears here,” it told him.

seg.q: êkwah osîhtamawin ahcâpiy êkwah acosisah êkwah môhkomân , napakihkomân , êkwah câpihcikanis ;
seg.gloss: “Then make me a bow, and arrows, and a knife, a bowie-knife, and a lance;
I shall hold these things in my hand.
If I see a bear, I shall kill it.”

p.seg: osîhtamâk kahkiyaw êwakoni . It made all these things for him.
êkwah ntawi-môminêw ; nîmâskwêw . Then he went and ate berries; he was armed.
kêtahtawê mêkwâc êh-môminêt , kâ-pâpahtâyit wâkayôsah . Presently, while he was eating berries, a bear came running.
nakiskawêw ; kêkwah otinêw ohcahcâpiyah mîna wîpisisah . He encountered it; he took his bow and his arrows.
pimwêw . He shot at it.
pîkohtitâw kahkiyaw piyis wîpisisah . In the end he broke all his arrows as he shot them.
ohcahcâpiyah ohci pakamahwêw ; pîkosimêw . He struck it with his bow; it broke as he brought it down.
êkwah omôhkomân otinam ; tahkamêw ; pîkohtitâw omôhkomân . Then he took his knife; he stabbed at the bear; he broke his knife with the thrust.
wêpinam . He threw it away.
êkwah otinam câpihcikanis ; pîkohtitâw . Then he took his spear; when he landed it, it broke.
êkwah misi-mistikwah itâmôw . Then he fled to a big tree.
waskâpahtâw êkotah mistikohk . He ran round the tree.
wâsâkamêtisahok wâkayôsah . The bear chased him round it.
wîh-nipahatâhtam . He was almost dead for loss of breath.
kîtahtawê moskiwêpiskam ostikwân , mostosostikwân . Then at one time he struck with his foot and uncovered a skull, a buffalo-skull.
kiskêyihtam êwakô êh-kostamiyit . He knew that the other feared this object.
pimi-naskwêpitam , êkwah ostikwânihk êh-akonahk . So in running past he grabbed it up and pulled it over his head.
môskîstawêw wâkayôsah . He attacked the bear.
mitoni mâkohêw . He drove it hard.

seg.gloss: It's my turn to drive you hard;
you had me at close quarters, you know, Bear!”

p.seg: êkwah pâhpiw mistahi , êh-mâkohât wâkayôsah . And he laughed greatly as he drove fear into the bear.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.
mâskôc kotak wâpamakih , nka-nipahik , itêyihtam êkwa wîsahkêcâhk . “Perhaps if I see another one, it will kill me,” thought Wisahketchahk.
sipwêhtêw ; pâ-pimohtêw . He went away; he tramped along.
wâskâhikan wâpahtam , mistah êh-mâyâtahk waskâhikanis . He saw a house, a very ugly little house.
nika-paspâpin , têyihtam . “I shall peek in through the door,” he thought.
paspâpiw , kâ-wâpamât wîhtikôwa êh-wâpamoyit . He peeked in and saw a Windigo looking into a mirror.
êkwah tanis êh-tôtamiyit êkosi tôtam . Then whatever the other did, he did the same.

êkwah awa wîhtikôw ,
tâpwê , nimiyôsin . Then that Windigo said, “Really, I am handsome.

seg.gloss: Really, I am throwing away my gifts, to be eating men.

p.seg: nka-wêpinên niwiyâsimah , itwêw . I shall throw away my meat.”
êkosi awa wâh-wêpinam owiyâsimah . So the Windigo threw away her supply of meat.
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk tapasîw . Then Wisahketchahk ran away.
êkwah awa wîhtikôw kahkiyaw ê-kîh-wêpinahk owiyâsimah , êkwah wâpamôw . Then, when the Windigo had thrown away all her stores of meat, then she looked into her mirror.
kakwâhyakinâkosiw . Her appearance was frightful.

seg.gloss: I will kill you, now I have ruined my meat.”

p.seg: nawaswêw êkwah awa wîhtikôw . Then the Windigo went in pursuit.
êkwah mâkwêyimôw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was in mortal fright.
kisiwâk êkw askôk ; wîpac atimik . Now the other was close upon him; quickly she caught him.

êkwah êh-atimikot ,
nikohtê , wîsahkêcâhk ! And when she had caught him, “Gather sticks, Wisahketchahk!”
êkwah nikohtêw . Then he gathered sticks.
papâ-mâtôw wîsahkêcâhk , êkwah ê-wîh-nipahiht . Wisahketchahk wept as he went about, for now he was going to be killed.
êkwah êh-astamawât mihtah , êkwah wîhtikôw awa pônam . And when he placed the sticks for the Windigo, the latter built a fire with them.
êkwah sipwêhtêw ; papâ-mâcosiw . So he went off; he whimpered as he went about.
kêtahtawê kâ-wâpamât sihkosah . Then presently he saw a weasel.
namoya ; sâm kiwîh-nipahin , itik ôhi sihkosah . “No; you mean to kill me,” the weasel answered him.
piyis itohtêyiwah . At last it came.
â , nisîm , niwîh-nipahik wîhtikôw , itêw ; “Little Brother, a Windigo wants to kill me,” he told it;

seg.gloss: “Try to do something or other to her.

p.seg: k-êsi-miyosiyan k-êsîhitin , itêw . I shall fix you so that you will be beautiful,” he, said to it.
êhag , itwêw sihkos . “Very well,” said the weasel.
êkwah wîhtikôwah ispayiw êokô sihkos . Then the weasel went to where the Windigo was.
kwayasitêw otôniyihk ; otêhiyiw paspaskêhtam . It slipped into her mouth; it bit apart her heart.

êkwah awa wîhtikôw ,
kiyipah pêtâ kitapwânâsk ! piyis nânitaw niwîh-is-âyân , êh-nôhtêhkatêyân , itik awa wîsahkêcâhk . Then the Windigo, “Quickly bring your spit! What with all this delay, I am feeling queer from hunger,” she said to Wisahketchahk.
êkwah is itohtêw . So he went there.
pê-pasikôyiwah êh-wîh-pê-nawaswâtikot . The other arose and came chasing him.
êkwah tapasîw , kâ-pê-kâskipitikot . Then he fled, the other just managing to graze him with her claws.

misi-mâ-mawimôw ,
yêy yêh ! êh-itwêt êôkô wîsahkêcâhk . Loudly he lamented, crying, “Yeh ya!” that Wisahketchahk.
mâkôhik wîhtikôwah . The Windigo was pressing close upon him.
mâka nôhtaw nipiyiwa . But she died before she got him.
nipahtwâk sihkosah . The weasel had killed her for him.
êkwah otinêw . Then he took it up.
êkos âni ninipahikoh wîhtikôw , itêw ; That Windigo would certainly have killed me,” he said to it;

seg.gloss: “And now, in winter you will be white;
your tail will have a little black at the tip.
And in summer you will be brown;
but your tail will be black in the same way.

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he went away.
mêkwâc êh-pa-pimohtêt , kêtahtawê ayisiyiniwah wâpamêw . As he wandered along, presently he saw some people.
nâh-nawaswêwân . There was much pursuing.
ay-ayâw êkotah . He stayed there.
kêtahtawê pêyak oskinîkiwah nôhtê-ayâwêyiwah iskwêwah . Then at one time a certain youth wanted to have a wife.
osâm kistêyimôw aw ôskinîkiw . That young man was too conceited.
kêtahtawê wîsahkêcâhk iskwêw osîhisôw . Then soon, Wisahketchahk made himself into a woman.
miyosiw awa wîsahkâcâhk ; mistahi miyosiw . Handsome was this Wisahketchahk; he was very handsome.
êkwah ntaw-onâpêmiw ôh ôskinîkiwah kâ-kihcêyimoyit . Then he went to take as a husband that conceited young man.
mahîhkanisah nîso otâpahêw . He had two young wolves to draw his sled.
êkwah wîkihk otâpêyiwah . And they drew his tent.
êkwah ôw oskinîkiw miywêyimêw ôh ôskinîkiskwêwah . And the young man took a liking to this young woman.
tâpwê miyosiw , nêkây , itêw okâwiyah ; “Truly, she is handsome, Mother,” he told his mother;
mahti nitom , itêw . “Do invite her,” he told her.

êkwah ,
êhag , itwêw nôtokêsiw . Then, “Yes,” said the old woman.
êkwah itohtêw . Then she went there.

îh , itwêw awa wîsahkêcâhk ,
tânihki ? “Ho,” said that Wisahketchahk, “What for?”

seg.gloss: “Because my son wants to see you.”

p.seg:
êkwah ,
êhag . Then, “Very well.”

mihcêt oskinîkiwak ê-nôhtê-wîkimicik êh-pê-tapasiyân , itêw ,
nistês ,
sipwêhtê , êh-isit . “It is because so many young men wanted to marry me, that I ran away and came here,” he told her; “My elder brother having told me, 'Go away'.”

êkwah nôtokêsiw ,
niya mînah nikosis êh-pê-tapasît ; Then the old woman, “My son too ran away and came here;

seg.gloss: because so many wanted to marry him is why he ran away and came here.”

p.seg: kah ! itêw aw îskwêw . “You don't say!” that woman answered her.
êkwah kîwêhtahik . Then the other took her home.
ntaw-onâpêmiw ôkosisiyiwa ôhi . She went to take that young man for her husband.
wâpamêw oskinîkiwah ; mistahi miyosiyiwa . She saw the young man; he was very handsome.
onâpêmiw kinwês . She was married to him for a long time.
kakâyawisiw mistahi . She was a very good worker.
kêtahtawê kinwês êh-onâpêmit , nôhtê-sipwêhtêw . At length, when she had been married to him for quite a while, she wanted to leave that place.
kêtahtawê cawâsimisiw mahîhkanisah . Then at one time she had babies, those wolf-cubs.
tahkopitâwasôw . She tied up her babies.
êkwah sâkihêw êh-wîh-wâpamâyit osikosah . She would not let her mother-in-law see them.
kêtahtawê nîpâtipisk sipwêhtêw êyôkô wîsahkêcâhk ; cawâsimisah nakatêw . Then one night Wisahketchahk departed; he left his babies behind.
êkwah nôtokêsiw êkwah kisêyiniw ntawi-wâpamêwak ôsisimiwâwah . Then the old woman and the old man came to look at their grandchildren.
êh-otinâcik pôt ôhih mahîhkanisah . When they took them up, why, they were wolf-cubs.

êhêy , itwêw nôtokêsiw ,
wîsahkêcâhk ês ôyâh ! “Oho,” cried the old woman, “So that person was Wisahketchahk!”
pâhpiw mahîhkanisah kâ-tahkopitât , k-ôcawâsimisit êôkôh oskinîkiw ê-nêpêwisit . She laughed as she swaddled those wolf-puppies which the young man, to his great embarrassment, had for babies.
kotakah ayîsiyiniwah pâhpihik . The other people laughed at him.

seg.q: tâpwê mistahi isîhcikêw oskinîkiw , wîsahkêcâhkwah êh-wîwit !
seg.gloss: “Truly, great things has this young man accomplished, in having Wisahketchahk for his wife!

seg.q: êkwah ka-pâhpinânaw , êh-kihcêyimot oskinîkiw êh-wîwit wîci-nâpêwah wîsahkêcâhkwah .
seg.gloss: Now we shall have something to laugh about, seeing that this conceited young man had Wisahketchahk, a man, as his wife!”

p.seg: êkwah pâhpiwak mistahi . And they laughed a great deal.

omis îtwêw :
kiyâm pikw îs isinâkosici iskwêw nika-wîwin . hus he spoke: “I don't care what sort of a looking woman I marry.
mistahi ninêpêwihik wîsahkêcâhk , itwêw . Wisahketchahk has put me to great shame,” he said.
kêtahtawê êh-pa-pmohtêt , kâ-wâpahtahk mîkiwâhp . Presently, as he wandered along, he saw a lodge.
nîpawiw wayawîtimihk . He stood outside.

êkwah ,
pîhtokê , k-êtikot iskwêwah ,
kipê-wîwin , itêw . Then, “Come in,” said the woman to him, “I have come to take you to wife,” he said to her. CHECK kipê-wîwin
êh-pîhtokêt , pôt ôhih pitokôkiyiwah . When he entered, she was all round, like a ball.
êkwah nahapîstawêw ; wîwîw . Then he sat beside her; he took her to wife.
êkwah nama wîhkâc wayawiyiwah êh-tipiskâyik . And she never went out at night.
êkwah mînah nêpêwisiw êh-pitikôkiyit êh-wîwit . And again he was ashamed, because he had that dumpy woman to wife.
êkotah sipwêhtêwak . They went away from there.
kîkisêpâ wawêyiwak . Early in the morning they made ready.
wâkayôsah otêmiw iskwêw ; otâpahêw . The woman had a bear as her beast of burden; she made it draw her sled.
kîwêw oskinîkiw ; kîwêpiciw ; otaskîwâhk ispiciw . The young man went home; he moved back home; he moved camp to his people's country.
êkwah êh-takopicit , pasikôyiwah wîwah . When he arrived with his household, his wife rose to her feet.
namoya êkwah pitikôkiyiwa . She was no longer short and dumpy.
êkwah êkotah wîsahkêcâhk pâhpiw . There was Wisahketchahk laughing.
kihcêyimôw oskinîkiw wîsahkêcâhkwah kîh-wîwiw , itêw . “The proud young man had Wisahketchahk for his wife,” he said to him.
nakiskawêw . He had gone to meet him.
êkwah wîkimêw anihi kotakah . And he had married this other one too.
êkosi wiy êokô . That is the end of this story.
